config.question: What did the Native American leaders, Tenskwatawa and Tecumseh, attempt to achieve?

choices.content: the transformation of Indians into yeoman farmers
a unified attack against white Americans

answer_3.response: Small groups of Native Americans, allegedly representing the interests of an entire tribe, had been selling off huge pieces of land, often for whiskey and trinkets. Such fraudulent transactions disgusted the Shawnee leaders Tenskwatawa (known as the Prophet) and his brother Tecumseh. Tecumseh rejected classification as a Shawnee and may have been the first native leader to identify himself self-consciously as “Indian.” These men attempted to revitalize native cultures. Against overwhelming odds, they briefly persuaded Native Americans living in the Indiana Territory to avoid contact with whites, resist alcohol, and, most important, hold on to their land.
